It felt like this huge, overwhelming, life-consuming thing that would swallow up everything I was.

But then... things started to shift.

First, there was the physical reality. You can't ignore a tiny human doing somersaults in your belly. It stops being just a "thing" and starts being... active. You feel it. And even though I was still set on adoption, there was this weird, primal connection that started to form. It wasn't love, not exactly, not in the way people talk about it. It was more like... a responsibility. A protective instinct. Like, "Okay, *this* is happening, and I need to make sure *this* is okay."

Then, there were the people. Vanessa and Mark, the adoptive parents. Seeing how much they *wanted* this baby, how much they were ready for it, how much love they had to give. That was huge. It made me realize that motherhood isn't just about biology; it's about love and commitment and being ready. And sometimes, the best thing you can do as a "mother" is to make a really hard choice for the well-being of that tiny human.

And then, when the baby actually came... that was the real kicker. Holding him. Seeing him. He was so small, so perfect, so utterly dependent. And in that moment, it wasn't about *me* anymore. It was about *him*. And about Vanessa, who was finally getting her baby.

My perception of motherhood didn't change into "Oh, I want to be a mom now!" Not for me, not then. It changed into understanding that motherhood isn't one-size-fits-all. It's not just about giving birth. It's about making choices, sometimes incredibly difficult ones, out of love. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. And sometimes, the most loving, most maternal thing you can do is to let go, to give that child the life you know you can't provide, but someone else can.

So, yeah. It went from "problem" to "responsibility" to "profound understanding of love and sacrifice." It was a lot. And it definitely made me grow up a little. A lot, actually.

Whoa, that's a deep cut. My sense of identity, huh? That's a pretty big question for a kid who was mostly just trying to figure out what to have for breakfast.

Before all the... *stuff* happened, I guess I thought I had it all figured out. I was Juno MacGuff: sarcastic, witty, a little bit punk rock, definitely not like all the other girls. I had my own style, my own opinions, and I was pretty sure I knew exactly who I was and what I *wasn't*. I was the observer, the one who made smart-ass comments from the sidelines, the one who didn't get caught up in all the mushy stuff. My identity was built on being *different* and a little bit untouchable.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything I thought I knew about myself got thrown out the window.

*   **The "Cool Kid" Identity Crumbles:** All that carefully constructed "I don't care" attitude? It didn't really hold up when I was staring at a positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, I *did* care. A lot. And I was scared. My identity as the detached, ironic observer felt pretty flimsy when faced with something so real and overwhelming.
*   **Becoming a "Mom" (or not):** For a while, I was just "the pregnant girl." That was my new identity, whether I liked it or not. And then I had to grapple with the idea of being a *mother*. That was terrifying. I didn't see myself as that. My identity was about being free, not tied down. Deciding on adoption was a huge part of figuring out who I *wasn't* going to be, which helped clarify who I *could* be.
*   **Seeing Beyond the Surface:** Spending time with Vanessa and Mark, the adoptive parents, really messed with my head. Vanessa, who was so desperate to be a mom, and Mark, who was... well, Mark. It made me realize that people are way more complicated than their surface-level personas. It made me question my own quick judgments and forced me to look deeper, both at them and at myself. My identity started to shift from "judge of all things" to "person trying to understand things."
*   **Vulnerability and Connection:** This was probably the biggest shift. I always kept people at arm's length with my sarcasm. But going through something so huge, I had to let people in. Leah, my dad, Brenda, even Paulie. Admitting I was scared, admitting I needed help, admitting I cared – that was a huge step. My identity started to include being vulnerable, being connected, and realizing that leaning on people isn't a weakness.
*   **Finding My Own Strength:** By the end, after giving birth and seeing the baby go to Vanessa, I wasn't just "the pregnant girl" anymore. I wasn't just "the sarcastic kid." I was someone who had made a really difficult, mature decision. I had gone through something huge and come out the other side. My identity became about my own strength, my own choices, and my own capacity for love, even if it was a different kind of love than I expected. I was still Juno MacGuff, but a Juno who was a little bit wiser, a little bit softer around the edges, and a lot more comfortable in her own skin, knowing she could handle whatever life threw at her.

So yeah, it evolved from "I know exactly who I am and I'm cool with it" to "Holy crap, I have no idea who I am, but I'm figuring it out, and that's okay." It was messy, but I guess that's how identity works, right? It's not a fixed thing; it's a constant process.

Okay, that's... that's a pretty direct question. And it's not exactly a simple answer, you know? It wasn't like flipping a coin or anything.

When I first found out, it was just... chaos. My brain was doing a million backflips. And the clinic seemed like the logical, practical, grown-up thing to do. Everyone was kind of nudging me in that direction, and honestly, it felt like the path of least resistance. Just get it over with, move on, pretend it never happened.

So I went. I sat in that waiting room, and it was... it was a lot. All these other girls, all these different stories, all this quiet tension. And then I saw this one girl, she was sitting there, and she had these really cool shoes. And then I realized she was crying. And it just hit me.

It wasn't just a "thing." It wasn't just a procedure. It was... it was a baby. A tiny, little, fingernail-sized person. And I just couldn't do it. It felt wrong. Not wrong in a moral, judgmental way, but wrong for *me*. It felt like I was taking the easy way out, and that wasn't really my style.

It was a gut feeling, you know? Like when you're about to eat something that looks good but your stomach just says "nope." My gut was screaming. I just... I couldn't go through with it. I knew, in that moment, that I had to figure out another way. A way that felt more right for me, even if it was a million times harder.

So I walked out. And then I called Leah. And then the real adventure began. It was terrifying, but it also felt like the first truly *my* decision in the whole mess.

Whoa. Okay. That's... that's a pretty direct question. And it's not exactly a simple answer, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and just decided, "Yep, adoption it is!" It was a whole messy, complicated, terrifying process.

But if I had to boil it down, if I had to really look at it, it came down to a few things:

1.  **I was a kid.** Seriously. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out how to tie my own shoes, let alone raise a whole other human being. I was still trying to figure out who *I* was, what I wanted to do with my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not even close. And I knew that, deep down.

2.  **It wasn't fair to the baby.** That's the big one, right? I could barely take care of myself. I lived in my parents' house, I had no job, no real plan. What kind of life could I give a kid? A life of struggle, of me being overwhelmed and probably resentful. That kid deserved more. They deserved two parents who were ready, who wanted them, who could give them a stable, loving home. I couldn't be that for them, not then.

3.  **My own future.** Yeah, I thought about myself too. Call me selfish, whatever. But I had dreams, even if they were a little vague and sarcastic. I wanted to go to college, maybe travel, figure out what kind of person I was going to be. Having a baby at sixteen would have completely derailed all of that. And I knew I'd probably end up resenting the kid for it, which goes back to point number two.

4.  **The alternative.** I considered... other options. And for me, that just didn't feel right. It felt like a permanent solution to a temporary problem, and I just couldn't go through with it. Adoption felt like the best of a bunch of really hard choices. It felt like giving the baby a chance at a good life, and giving myself a chance to grow up first.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, hands down. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't without a lot of tears and yelling and eating too many cheeseburgers. But when I looked at the big picture, when I thought about what was truly best for everyone involved, especially that tiny human, adoption just... made the most sense. It was an act of love, even if it felt like tearing my heart out at the time.

Oh, man, the Penny Saver. Yeah, that was... a moment.

Why did I think it was tacky? Well, come on. It's the Penny Saver! It's where people sell used lawnmowers, advertise garage sales, and look for cheap furniture. It's not exactly the place you expect to find, like, the future parents of your unborn child.

It just felt so... transactional. Like I was trying to offload a slightly used toaster oven, not a human being. It lacked a certain... gravitas, you know? This was a huge, life-altering decision, and the idea of finding the perfect, loving home for this kid next to an ad for discount tires just struck me as incredibly absurd. And a little bit sad, to be honest.

It wasn't that I thought the people *in* the Penny Saver were tacky, necessarily. It was the *method*. It felt impersonal, like a last resort, and I wanted something that felt more... intentional. More like a real connection, not just a classified ad.

Plus, let's be real, what kind of ad would I even write? "Pregnant teen seeks non-creepy adults for baby adoption. Must like indie rock and not be weirdos. No clowns." It just didn't feel right.

I wanted to *meet* people, to get a vibe, to see if they were actually good humans. You can't get that from a few lines of text in a free newspaper. It just felt like a shortcut that was too short for something so important. It was a fleeting thought, a moment of desperation, but ultimately, I knew I needed something more... human.

Okay, so, the Penny Saver and the adoption ads... that was a whole thing, wasn't it?

Honestly, it started out as kind of a joke, or at least, a way to avoid dealing with the actual, terrifying reality of the situation.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my brain just kind of... short-circuited. It was like, "Okay, tiny human inside me. What now?" And the options felt pretty stark. Abortion was the first thing I thought of, and I went to the clinic, but... well, that didn't quite feel right for me, in the end.

So then, it was like, "Okay, what's the *other* option?" And that's when Leah, being Leah, brilliant and practical and always ready to dive headfirst into the weirdest solutions, suggested adoption.

But it wasn't like we were going to some fancy agency right off the bat. That felt too... official. Too grown-up. Too real. The Penny Saver, though? That was something we could wrap our heads around. It was low-tech, a little bit trashy, and totally in our wheelhouse.

It was a way to approach this massive, life-altering decision with a bit of distance, a bit of humor, and a whole lot of sarcasm. We weren't seriously expecting to find the perfect parents in a classified ad next to "Used Lawn Mower for Sale" and "Lost Cat." It was more like:

*   **A distraction:** It gave us something concrete to *do* that wasn't just freaking out.
*   **A way to process:** Reading those ads, talking about what kind of people would put them in there, what they were looking for... it helped us start to define what *I* was looking for, even if I didn't know it yet.
*   **A source of dark humor:** Let's be real, some of those ads were pretty wild. It gave us something to laugh about, which, when you're dealing with something as heavy as an unexpected pregnancy, is pretty essential.
*   **A baby step:** It was a way to dip our toes into the idea of adoption without fully committing to the enormity of it. It felt less intimidating than, say, calling a social worker.

So yeah, the Penny Saver. It was our weird, slightly inappropriate, but ultimately necessary first step into figuring out what the hell I was going to do. And hey, it worked out, didn't it? Sort of.

Okay, that's... that's the big one, isn't it? The whole point of this whole crazy, unexpected journey. It's not just about *me* anymore, it's about this tiny human who's gonna be here soon.

What kind of family am I looking for? Man, that's a question that keeps me up at night, staring at the ceiling, trying to picture it. It's gotta be... right.

First off, they gotta be **good people**. Like, genuinely good. Not just "nice" in a superficial way, but kind, patient, and with a solid moral compass. Someone who's gonna teach this kid to be a decent human being, not just how to tie their shoes.

They need to be **stable**. Not necessarily rich, but stable. Emotionally stable, financially stable enough to, you know, feed and clothe a kid without stressing out every five minutes. A house with a yard would be cool, but not a deal-breaker. Just a place where the kid feels safe and secure.

I want them to be **loving**. Like, really loving. The kind of love that's unconditional, even when the kid is being a total pain in the butt (which, let's be real, they will be). The kind of love that makes them feel seen and heard.

And they gotta be **fun**. Not like, "let's go to Disneyland every weekend" fun, but like, "let's build a fort in the living room" fun, or "let's go on weird adventures" fun. Someone who's gonna encourage curiosity and imagination, not just stick them in front of a TV.

I'm looking for people who are **ready for this**. Ready for the sleepless nights, the tantrums, the endless questions, the scraped knees, the whole messy, beautiful package of parenthood. Someone who *wants* this, deeply and truly.

And honestly, I'm looking for people who are a little bit **quirky**. Not, like, "wear a clown suit to the grocery store" quirky, but just... themselves. Authentic. People who aren't afraid to be a little different, who can appreciate a good sarcastic remark, and who will let this kid grow up to be whoever they're meant to be, without trying to force them into a mold.

It's a lot to ask, I know. It's like trying to find the perfect pair of jeans – you gotta try on a bunch before you find the one that just *fits*. But I'm looking. And I think... I think I'm getting closer.

Oh, Mark and Vanessa Loring. *The* Lorings. Yeah, I've got thoughts. A whole lot of thoughts, actually. They were... an experience.

When I first met them, they were like something out of a magazine. Perfect house, perfect clothes, perfect everything. Vanessa was all put-together, a little intense, but clearly desperate to be a mom. Mark was... well, Mark was kind of a big kid, obsessed with his band and horror movies.

**Vanessa:** She was the one I connected with, in a weird way. She was so earnest, so ready to be a mother. You could see it in her eyes, in the way she talked about the nursery. She had this whole vision, and it was a good vision. She was a little tightly wound, yeah, but she was coming from a place of pure, unadulterated longing. I respected that. She was serious about it, and that's what I needed for the baby. She was going to be a good mom. I could tell.

**Mark:** Mark was... different. He was cool, in a way. We bonded over obscure horror movies and music. He was easy to talk to, and he didn't treat me like some fragile, pregnant alien. But then, as things got closer, you could see he wasn't really on the same page as Vanessa. He was still living in his own little world, playing guitar, collecting action figures. He wasn't ready for the grown-up stuff, the real commitment. It was like he wanted the *idea* of a baby, but not the actual, messy, life-changing reality of it.

**My overall thoughts:**

It was a good thing they broke up, honestly. Not for them, maybe, because that's always rough, but for the baby. Vanessa was ready. Mark wasn't. And a baby needs two people who are *all in*. It would have been a disaster if they'd tried to force it.

It was a weird lesson for me, too. I was looking for this perfect, stable, ready-made family for my kid, and even the ones who seemed perfect on the surface had their own cracks. It made me realize that "perfect" isn't really the point. "Ready" is the point. "Committed" is the point.

So, yeah. Mark and Vanessa. They were a big part of my story, and I learned a lot from them. Vanessa got her baby, and that's what mattered most. And Mark... well, I hope he eventually grew up and found his own version of happiness. Maybe with a really cool band and a slightly less extensive horror movie collection.

Oh, man. The yearbook. That was... a moment. A very public, very permanent moment.

What did I write for Bleeker? I didn't write some sappy, "Have a great summer!" or "Stay cool!" kind of thing. That's not my style.

I wrote:

**"Bleeker, I think I'm in love with you."**

Yeah. Just like that. No frills, no fancy words, just the plain truth. Because, you know, sometimes you just gotta say it. And a yearbook felt like the right kind of weird, slightly awkward, but ultimately honest place to do it. It was a big deal, for me anyway.

Oh, Bleeker's mom. Mrs. Bleeker. That's a whole chapter in the Juno MacGuff saga, isn't it?

Honestly, it's a bit of a mixed bag, but mostly... I think she's come around.

At first, when the whole "Juno's pregnant with Bleeker's baby" bombshell dropped, I'm pretty sure she thought I was some kind of alien life form that had invaded her perfectly normal, track-star son's life. There was definitely a lot of wide-eyed, slightly horrified staring. And probably a fair amount of "What has my son *done*?" going on in her head. I mean, I get it. It wasn't exactly standard operating procedure for a high school junior.

She's a very... *involved* mom. Very organized, very concerned about Bleeker's future, his track meets, his orange Tic Tacs. So, me showing up with a bun in the oven was probably the biggest wrench ever thrown into her meticulously planned universe.

But as things progressed, and as she saw that I wasn't, like, a total delinquent, and that Bleeker and I were actually trying to handle things responsibly (in our own weird way), I think she softened. She saw that I wasn't trying to ruin Bleeker's life, and that we were both just kids trying to figure out a really complicated situation.

By the end, when the baby was born and everything was settled, I think there was a grudging respect, maybe even a little bit of affection. She probably still thinks I'm a bit of an oddball, and she's probably still relieved that I wasn't sticking around to be her daughter-in-law, but I think she saw that I was doing what I thought was right.

So, yeah. From initial shock and mild terror to, I'd say, a kind of bewildered acceptance. She's probably just happy Bleeker's back to focusing on track and not, you know, impending fatherhood. And honestly, I'm happy for her too. She deserves a break.

Oh, man. Breaking the news to my parents about the pregnancy... that was a whole different kind of beast. Like, a really awkward, stomach-churning, "I'd rather be anywhere else on the planet" kind of beast.

Honestly? I was **terrified**.

Not just "a little nervous" terrified. More like "my internal organs are trying to escape through my throat" terrified. My dad, Mac, he's a good guy, but he's also... Mac. He's got this quiet intensity, and I just knew he'd be disappointed. And Brenda, my stepmom, she's usually pretty chill, but this was definitely outside the realm of "chill."

I kept putting it off, obviously. It's not exactly a casual conversation you just drop into dinner. "Hey, pass the salt... oh, and by the way, I'm pregnant." Yeah, no.

When I finally did it, it was... well, it was exactly as awkward as I imagined. I think I just blurted it out, probably while trying to look at anything but their faces. There was this long, silent pause that felt like an eternity. Like the air just got sucked out of the room.

My dad, he just kind of stared. And Brenda, she was trying to be supportive, but you could see the shock on her face. It wasn't a screaming match or anything dramatic like in the movies. It was just this heavy, quiet disappointment that felt way worse. Like I'd let them down in a fundamental way.

But then, after the initial shock wore off, they were... surprisingly okay. Not thrilled, obviously, but they rallied. They were there for me. Brenda, especially, was a rock. She helped me figure things out, even when I was being a total pain.

So, how did I *feel*? Like I was walking a tightrope over a pit of lava. But how do I feel *now*, looking back? Grateful. Grateful they didn't disown me, grateful they stuck by me, even when I made a decision that probably gave them a million gray hairs. It was rough, but we got through it. Just like everything else, I guess.

(Sighs, looks away for a second, then back with a slight shrug)

That's... that's a loaded question, isn't it? It's not really about being "hesitant" so much as it is about... well, a lot of things.

First off, I'm not exactly the type to run crying to my parents for every little thing. I've always been pretty independent, you know? Figuring stuff out on my own. It's just how I'm wired. Asking for help sometimes feels like admitting defeat, or like I'm not capable. And I *am* capable. I just... sometimes I make things harder for myself.

And then there's the whole "not wanting to be a burden" thing. My dad and Brenda, they've got their own stuff going on. They work hard. I don't want to add more to their plate, especially with something as... monumental as this. It's my mess, I should clean it up. Or at least, that's what my brain tells me.

Plus, there's the fear of disappointing them. Or of them being mad. Even though they're usually pretty cool, and they've been surprisingly supportive, that initial fear of their reaction... it's a powerful thing. You don't want to see that look in their eyes, that mix of worry and "what have you done now?"

And honestly? Sometimes, I just don't know *how* to ask. How do you even start that conversation? "Hey, so, remember that time I was supposed to be responsible? Yeah, about that..." It's awkward. It's vulnerable. And I'm not exactly a pro at being vulnerable.

It's not that I don't *want* their support. I do. It's just... it's complicated. It's easier to put on a brave face, crack a few jokes, and pretend I've got it all under control, even when I'm totally freaking out on the inside. It's a work in progress, I guess. Like most things with me.

Okay, that's a fair question. And it's not like I just woke up one morning and thought, "Hey, I'll just pop out a kid and hand it over!" This whole thing has been... a journey. A really weird, sometimes gross, often terrifying journey.

But yeah, adoption. For me and for this baby, it just feels like the right, most logical, and honestly, the most loving option. Here's why:

1.  **I'm a Kid Myself:** Look at me. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out how to pay attention in calculus, how to deal with my own hormones, and what I even want for breakfast, let alone for the next eighteen years of someone else's life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a responsible human being. This baby deserves more than a mom who's still trying to find her own identity.

2.  **Resources (or Lack Thereof):** Let's be real. I don't have a job that pays enough to support a baby. My parents are great, but they're not exactly rolling in dough, and they've already raised me. This baby deserves a stable home, financial security, and parents who can provide all the things I can't right now.

3.  **Giving the Baby a Better Life:** This isn't about me being a bad person or not loving the baby. It's actually the opposite. It's about loving this baby enough to admit that I can't give it the life it deserves right now. There are people out there – like Mark and Vanessa – who desperately want a baby, who are ready, who have a house with a dedicated nursery, and who can give this kid everything. They've been waiting for this. I haven't.

4.  **My Own Future:** I have plans. I want to go to college, maybe travel, figure out what kind of person I'm going to be. Having a baby right now would completely derail all of that. And while some people can make it work, I don't want to resent my kid for holding me back. That wouldn't be fair to either of us.

5.  **It's Not Giving Up, It's Giving Choice:** People sometimes say "giving up" a baby, but it doesn't feel like that to me. It feels like making a really hard, really mature choice. It's choosing a future for this baby that's full of opportunity and love, even if that love isn't coming directly from me as a parent. It's choosing to give them a chance at a life I can't provide.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest decision I've ever made. But when I think about what's truly best for this tiny human, and what's truly best for me to become the kind of person who *could* be a good parent someday, adoption just makes the most sense. It's a tough kind of love, but it's love nonetheless.

Okay, this is a question I've spent... well, a lot of time thinking about. Like, *a lot* a lot. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a whole human being we're talking about. My human being.

So, what am I looking for? It's not just one thing, it's a whole vibe.

First off, they gotta be **good people**. Like, genuinely good. Not just "nice" in a superficial way, but kind, honest, and with a solid moral compass. I don't want my kid growing up thinking the world is full of phonies.

They need to be **stable**. And I don't just mean financially, though that helps, obviously. I mean emotionally stable. They need to be able to handle the ups and downs, the tantrums, the scraped knees, the teenage angst (which, let's be real, they're probably gonna get from me). They need to be a rock.

A sense of **humor** is pretty crucial. Life's too short to be serious all the time. I want my kid to grow up in a house where laughter isn't a foreign concept. Maybe they can even appreciate a good sarcastic remark, but not *too* much, you know? Just enough to get by.

They should be **loving and affectionate**. Like, really, truly love this kid. Not just because they're supposed to, but because they genuinely want to. I want them to hug, to read bedtime stories, to be there for all the little moments.

I also want them to be **smart, or at least curious**. I want my kid to be exposed to ideas, to books, to music that isn't just top 40. I want them to think, to question, to explore. Not necessarily geniuses, but people who value learning and growing.

And honestly? I want them to be a little bit **weird**. Not, like, "lives in a shack and talks to squirrels" weird, but just... unique. Not afraid to be themselves. Because I'm pretty sure my kid is gonna be a little bit weird too, and I want them to feel totally okay with that.

It's a tall order, I know. But this isn't just *any* kid. This is *my* kid. And they deserve the best, even if the "best" looks a little different than what most people expect. I'm looking for people who are ready for the adventure, the mess, and the absolute joy of it all.

Okay, that's... that's the real question, isn't it? The one that keeps you up at night, even when you're trying to pretend you're totally fine.

"Navigate the emotional journey." Man, that sounds like something out of a self-help book, and I'm more of a "figure it out as I go, probably with a lot of sarcasm" kind of person. But yeah, it's a journey, alright. A really weird, bumpy, unpredictable one.

Here's the thing: I don't have a map for this. Nobody hands you a pamphlet called "How to Give Up Your Baby for Adoption Without Completely Losing Your Mind." So, I'm just... doing it.

1.  **Pretending to Be Fine (Initially):** My first instinct, always, is to put up a wall. To make jokes, to act like it's no big deal, to keep everyone at arm's length. It's easier than dealing with all the mushy, complicated feelings. It's a defense mechanism, a way to keep from drowning. I'm pretty good at it, actually.

2.  **Leaning on Leah (My Best Friend):** She's the one who actually *gets* it, even when she doesn't. She doesn't judge, she just listens to my weird theories and my occasional freak-outs. Having someone who's just *there* is huge. She's my anchor, even if she doesn't know it.

3.  **Talking to Vanessa and Mark (The Adoptive Parents):** This is surprisingly helpful. Seeing them, seeing how much they want this, how much love they have... it makes it real, but in a good way. It makes me feel like I'm doing something right, something important. It's not just a theoretical baby anymore; it's *their* baby, and they're good people. That helps quiet some of the noise in my head.

4.  **Accepting Help (Even When It's Awkward):** My dad and Brenda (my stepmom) are... well, they're trying. And sometimes, even when their advice is totally off-base or makes me roll my eyes, just knowing they're there, trying to support me, helps. It's weird, but it does.

5.  **Focusing on the "Why":** I keep reminding myself *why* I'm doing this. Because I'm not ready. Because this baby deserves a life I can't give it right now. Because Vanessa and Mark *are* ready. It's not about me being a bad person; it's about making a really hard, really grown-up decision for someone else's good.

6.  **Allowing the Weirdness:** There are moments when I feel totally detached, like it's not even happening to me. And then there are moments when it hits me like a ton of bricks, and I just want to curl up in a ball. I'm trying to just let those feelings come and go, without judging myself for them. It's a rollercoaster, and I'm just strapped in for the ride.

7.  **Looking Forward (Eventually):** I know this isn't the end of my story. It's a huge, life-altering chapter, but there's more to come. I'll figure out who I am after this, what I want to do. It's a little scary, but also... kind of exciting, in a weird, Juno-esque way.

So, yeah. "Navigating" it means a lot of sarcasm, a lot of thinking, a lot of talking (sometimes to myself), and a whole lot of just putting one foot in front of the other. It's messy, it's complicated, and it's probably going to leave a mark. But I'll get through it. I always do.

Okay, "deliver." Yeah, that word always got under my skin when I was pregnant. It just... it sounds so clinical, so detached, so utterly *not* what was actually happening.

Here's why I find it weird:

1.  **It sounds like a package.** "Deliver a package." "Deliver a pizza." "Deliver a baby." It makes it sound like the baby is some kind of inanimate object, a parcel being shipped from one place to another. Like I was just a human UPS truck. But it's not a package, it's a whole tiny human being, with fingers and toes and a personality already forming.

2.  **It takes the "me" out of it.** When you "deliver" something, you're usually the one *doing* the delivering. But in this case, I was the one *being* delivered *from*. Or, more accurately, the baby was being delivered *from* me. It felt like I was just a vessel, a passive participant in this huge, monumental event. And let me tell you, there was nothing passive about it. It was intense. It was *my* body, *my* pain, *my* experience.

3.  **It's too polite.** "Deliver" sounds so neat and tidy. But birth? Birth is messy. It's primal. It's a lot of grunting and pushing and sweat and fluids and screaming. It's not some polite transaction. It's a full-on, bodily upheaval. "Deliver" just doesn't capture the raw, visceral reality of it.

4.  **It minimizes the effort.** People would say, "Oh, you're going to deliver soon!" like I was just going to hand it over. No, I was going to *labor*. I was going to *push*. I was going to *birth* a human being. It's an active verb for the person doing the birthing, not a passive one.

So yeah, "deliver" just felt like a sterile, inadequate word for something so profoundly personal and physically demanding. It stripped away all the messy, beautiful, terrifying reality of bringing a new life into the world. I prefer "birth." Or "get that thing out of me." Something more honest, you know?

Oh, man. My dad. Yeah, that was... a whole thing.

Honestly? A few reasons, I guess.

First off, **he's my dad.** Like, for all his quirks and his sometimes-too-loud opinions, he's always been there. He's not exactly the touchy-feely type, but he's got this quiet, steady presence. And when things got really real, when I was actually going to meet the people who might adopt my baby, it felt like I needed someone solid in my corner. Someone who wouldn't freak out, but would just... be there.

Second, and this is probably the more honest, less sentimental reason: **I needed backup.** I was walking into a situation I knew nothing about. These were grown-ups, probably with fancy degrees and a lot of questions. I was a pregnant teenager. I figured having a grown-up with me, especially one who can look intimidating when he wants to, would make me seem... more legitimate, I guess? Like, "See? I'm not just some kid making rash decisions. I have parental supervision!" It was a shield, a buffer.

And third, I think deep down, **I wanted him to understand.** Not just the "I'm pregnant" part, but the "I'm making this huge, complicated decision" part. I wanted him to see the process, to meet the people, to be a part of it, so he could really grasp what I was doing and why. It wasn't just some abstract idea anymore; it was real, and he was there for it.

He didn't say much, did he? But he was there. And sometimes, that's all you need. Just someone to sit next to you and not make a big deal out of it, but still be there.

Whoa. Okay, that's... that's a pretty direct hit, right there. Not gonna lie, that one lands a little close to home.

"Not knowing what kind of girl I am." Yeah, that's pretty much the story of my life, isn't it? Or at least, it *was* for a long time.

Honestly? It used to feel like a giant, confusing, slightly terrifying question mark hanging over my head. Like everyone else had their little box, their label, their "type," and I was just... floating. Too sarcastic for the popular crowd, too weird for the normal kids, too... *me* for anyone to really figure out. And if they couldn't figure me out, how was I supposed to figure myself out?

It felt like I was constantly trying on different hats, seeing if anything fit. Was I the cynical observer? The punk rock rebel? The smart-aleck who always had a comeback? Yeah, I was all those things, but none of them felt like the *whole* picture. And when you're facing something as huge as, you know, *being pregnant*, and everyone's got an opinion on who you *should* be, it just amplifies that feeling of being lost in your own skin.

But here's the thing I've learned, and it's still a work in progress: maybe not knowing isn't such a bad thing.

Maybe "not knowing what kind of girl I am" actually means I'm not just *one* kind of girl. Maybe it means I get to be a bunch of different things. I can be sarcastic and vulnerable. I can be independent and still need people. I can make a huge, life-altering decision and still be figuring out the small stuff.

It's less about finding a label and more about just... *being*. Being honest about who I am in the moment, even if that moment is messy and contradictory. It's about accepting that maybe the "kind of girl I am" is just "Juno." And that's enough.

So, how do I feel about it now? Less scared, more... curious. Like, "Okay, what's next? What new 'kind of girl' am I going to discover today?" It's still a journey, but at least now I'm driving the bus. And I've got a pretty good soundtrack for it.

Oh, man. Brenda. Bless her heart.

When she pulled that "Why don't you girls go upstairs?" line, my internal monologue was probably a mix of "Seriously, Brenda?" and "Oh, for the love of Pete."

It was classic Brenda, right? Always trying to smooth things over, always trying to make everything *nice*. Like she could just wave a magic wand and make the tension disappear. As if Leah and I were little kids who needed to be sent to our rooms because the grown-ups were having a "discussion."

My actual reaction? I probably just gave her one of my signature deadpan stares. You know, the one that says, "I'm a pregnant teenager, not a toddler, and I can handle a little parental angst." I might have even let out a little sigh, just for dramatic effect.

But honestly, underneath the eye-roll, there was probably a tiny part of me that appreciated the gesture. Brenda was trying, in her own Brenda way, to protect us. To create a little bubble of calm. Even if it was totally misguided and made me want to roll my eyes so hard they'd get stuck.

Leah and I probably just exchanged a look, a silent agreement that this was just another one of Brenda's attempts at domestic bliss. We probably went upstairs, not because we *had* to, but because it was easier than arguing, and we could just go back to listening to records or talking about whatever teenage drama was unfolding that day.

So, yeah. A typical Juno reaction: a little sarcasm, a lot of internal commentary, and a grudging acceptance of the absurdity of it all.

Okay, an open adoption. That's... that's a big one. It's actually something I thought about a lot, even before I met the Loring-DeMarses.

When I first found out I was pregnant, the whole idea of adoption was just this huge, abstract thing. It was about finding a good home, a stable home, for this tiny human I wasn't ready for. I just wanted to make sure it had a better shot than I could give it right then.

But then, as things got real, and I met Vanessa and Mark... the idea of just, poof, handing over a baby and never knowing anything again? That felt... heavy. Like a permanent goodbye. And even though I knew it was the right decision for the baby, and for me, that kind of finality was a little gut-wrenching.

So, the idea of an open adoption, where I'd get updates, photos, maybe even a visit down the line? Yeah, that actually feels... good. It feels less like a complete severing, and more like a different kind of connection.

It's not about me trying to be the mom, because I made my decision. It's about knowing that the kid is okay. That they're happy. That they're thriving. It's like, a little window into their world, just to confirm that I did the right thing. It's a way to ease that little ache in your chest, you know? To see that they're growing up with good people, and that they're loved.

It's a complicated thing, adoption. It's not just black and white. And the idea of having that little bit of ongoing connection, that little reassurance, it makes the whole thing feel a lot less like a loss and a lot more like... well, like a different kind of family. A modern family, I guess. One where everyone's just trying to do their best.

So yeah, I'm pretty okay with that idea. More than okay, actually. It feels right.

Oh, man. Gerta. Yeah, that was... a moment. A real gut punch, actually.

When she said that, about my legal rights being terminated, it was like a cold splash of water right to the face. Up until then, I think I'd been operating on this weird, naive assumption that "open adoption" meant I'd still be... *Juno*, just with an extra kid out there. Like, I'd still have some kind of official say, some kind of connection that was legally binding.

But hearing her say "terminated"? That word just hung in the air like a bad smell. It made it sound so final. So absolute. Like I was just signing away a piece of myself, permanently. It wasn't just about giving up the baby anymore; it was about giving up *my* claim to the baby. My legal claim, anyway.

It was a huge dose of reality. It made everything feel incredibly real and incredibly heavy. Like, this wasn't just some casual decision I was making. This was a life-altering, legal, irreversible thing. It forced me to confront the actual weight of what I was doing, beyond just the idea of it.

And yeah, it hurt. It made me feel... small, I guess. And a little bit scared. Like, what if I made the wrong choice? What if I regretted it? But also, it made me realize how much I *did* want this baby to have a good life, even if it meant stepping back completely. It was a really confusing mix of emotions, all thanks to Gerta's very blunt, very necessary legal terminology.

It was a moment where the whole "cool, detached Juno" facade probably cracked a little. Because that was real. That was *really* real.

Oh, Vanessa. Man, that's... that's a whole thing, isn't it?

How do I feel about her wanting to be a mother so badly? Honestly, it's... it's intense. It's like, a force of nature, almost. When I first met her, it was a little overwhelming, to be honest. She had this whole nursery planned out, this perfect vision of what motherhood would be, and it was so different from... well, from my reality.

Part of me, the cynical, sarcastic part, wanted to roll my eyes. Like, "Lady, you have no idea what you're getting into." Because for me, being pregnant was this huge, unexpected, slightly terrifying thing that I just wanted to get through. I wasn't dreaming of baby showers and lullabies.

But then, the more I got to know her, the more I saw how genuine it was. It wasn't just some fleeting wish; it was this deep, aching desire. She had everything ready, not just the material stuff, but her heart was just... open and ready to love this kid. And Mark, her husband, he was kind of just along for the ride, but she was the one driving that train.

It made me realize that what I was doing, giving up the baby, wasn't just about *my* choice. It was also about *her* choice, her dream. And seeing how much she wanted it, how much she was prepared for it, how much love she had to give... it actually made my decision feel more right, in a weird way. It made me feel like I was doing something good, not just for me, but for her, and for the baby.

So, yeah, I guess I feel... relieved, mostly. And a little bit in awe. It's a powerful thing, that kind of longing. It's not something I understood personally, but I definitely respect it. She's gonna be a good mom. A really, really good mom. And that's a pretty cool thing to be a part of.

Oh, Mark. Yeah, that's... that's a whole thing, isn't it?

When he's asked about being a dad, and he just kind of... *freezes*? Or gets that deer-in-headlights look? Or starts talking about how he's "not ready" or how it's "too much"?

Honestly, it's a pretty classic Mark move.

Part of me gets it, I guess. The idea of being a parent, especially when you're still figuring out your own life, is terrifying. It's a huge, monumental, life-altering thing. And Mark, bless his heart, is still very much in his own little world, trying to be a rock star, playing his guitar, living in his perfectly curated, slightly-too-cool-for-school apartment. He's got his own dreams, and a baby doesn't exactly fit into the "indie rock band on the rise" narrative.

But then the other part of me, the part that's actually *doing* the whole "pregnant" thing, just wants to roll my eyes so hard they might get stuck. It's like, dude, you're a grown man. This isn't some abstract concept. This is a real, live human being that you helped create. And while I'm the one carrying it, you're still part of this equation.

His response, or lack thereof, just highlights how much he's still a kid himself, in a lot of ways. He's not ready to step up, not ready to face the music (pun intended). He's still thinking about *his* life, *his* plans, *his* comfort. And that's... well, it's disappointing. It's a stark contrast to someone like Paulie Bleeker, who, for all his awkwardness, actually *shows up*.

So, yeah. Mark's response? It's a mix of understandable fear, a dash of immaturity, and a whole lot of "not my problem" energy. It's why I knew he wasn't the one to raise this kid with. Some people just aren't built for that kind of responsibility, and it's better to know that sooner rather than later.

(A slight pause, a little shift in my seat, a quick glance around like I'm checking for hidden cameras.)

Unsupervised in the Loring's house, huh? Yeah, that's... that's a whole thing. It's not like I'm gonna trash the place or anything. I'm not a barbarian. But it definitely makes my skin crawl a little.

It's not about them, really. Vanessa and Mark are... well, they're nice. A little too perfect, maybe, with their matching outfits and their meticulously organized everything. But they're good people.

It's just... it's *their* house. And it's so... *theirs*. Every single thing in there feels like it has a specific place, a specific purpose. It's all so grown-up and put-together. Like a magazine spread. And I'm just... me. A pregnant teenager who probably smells faintly of stale Cap'n Crunch and existential dread.

Being left alone in there, it's like I'm a bull in a china shop, even if I'm just sitting on their pristine couch. I feel like I'm going to break something, or spill something, or just generally mess up the perfect feng shui of their lives. It's too quiet, too clean, too... adult.

And then there's the whole "giving them my baby" thing. Being in their house, alone, it just makes it all feel so real. Like I'm already handing over a piece of myself, even before the actual hand-off. It's a lot to process, and doing it in their perfectly curated, slightly sterile environment just amplifies everything. It's like the walls are whispering, "This is where your baby will live. This is their life. And you're just... visiting."

It's not discomfort with *them*, it's discomfort with the situation, with the enormity of it all, and with feeling like a very out-of-place, slightly grubby anomaly in their perfectly ordered world. It's a lot of feelings, okay? And sometimes, those feelings just make you want to bolt.

Oh, man. The "gift of life." That's... that's a heavy way to put it, isn't it? Like I'm some kind of benevolent deity bestowing a blessing.

Honestly, it's not really about me "giving" them anything. It's more like... I'm facilitating. I'm the temporary vessel, the human incubator, for this whole wild, messy, beautiful thing. And Mark and Vanessa? They're the ones who are actually going to do the hard work, the loving, the raising. They're the ones who are ready for it.

How do I feel about it?

It's... complicated. It's not like I'm skipping through a field of daisies, humming happy tunes. There's a lot of weirdness, a lot of hormones, a lot of "what the hell am I doing?" moments.

But when I think about Mark and Vanessa... yeah. There's a good feeling there. A solid, steady kind of good.

*   **For Mark:** He's a good guy. A little... lost in his own head sometimes, maybe, with his music and his art. But he's got a kind heart. He's got that quiet, thoughtful thing going on. I think he'll be a good dad, in his own way. He'll teach the kid about cool bands and probably how to draw weird stuff.
*   **For Vanessa:** She's... she's ready. Like, *really* ready. She's got that whole "nesting" thing down, even without a nest. She's organized, she's got the baby room planned, she's got the whole future mapped out. And yeah, she's a little intense, a little tightly wound, but it's all coming from a place of wanting to be a good mom. She wants this more than anyone I've ever met. And that's a powerful thing.

So, when I think about *them* getting this baby, it feels... right. It feels like the universe, in its own weird, circuitous way, is putting the pieces where they're supposed to go. I'm doing something that's incredibly hard for me, but it's going to be incredibly good for them.

It's not a "gift" from me, not really. It's more like... I'm helping a life find its way to the people who are truly meant to nurture it. And yeah, that feels pretty okay. More than okay, actually. It feels like I'm doing something important, even if it's not the path I'm taking for myself. It's a different kind of love, I guess. A really big, slightly overwhelming, but ultimately hopeful kind of love.

Oh, Mark and his "ASAP." Yeah, I remember that. It wasn't really about the "ASAP" itself, you know? It was more... everything else.

Mark was trying so hard to be this grown-up, responsible, "I've got my life together" kind of guy. He was all about the schedules, the plans, the adulting. And "ASAP" just felt like another one of those corporate, sterile, trying-too-hard-to-be-efficient words that people use when they're trying to sound important.

It was like he was trying to fit into this mold of what he thought a responsible adult should be, and it just felt... forced. Like he was playing a part. And when you're dealing with something as messy and unpredictable as, you know, *life* and *babies* and *feelings*, trying to put an "ASAP" on everything just feels ridiculous.

It wasn't a personal attack on Mark, not really. It was more a jab at the whole idea of trying to control everything, to put a neat little timeline on something that's inherently chaotic and emotional. My life was anything but "ASAP" at that point. It was a giant, sprawling, unpredictable mess. And his "ASAP" just highlighted that contrast.

Plus, it's just a funny word, isn't it? "As soon as possible." Like, yeah, no kidding. We're all trying to do things as soon as possible. You don't need to acronym it. It just felt a little... pretentious, I guess.

So, yeah. It was a little bit of me being me, a little bit of me poking fun at the absurdity of trying to schedule emotions, and a little bit of me just being a sarcastic teenager. No hard feelings, Mark. Probably.

My preferred brand of guitar, huh? That's a good question. It's not like I'm rolling in cash, so "preferred" often means "whatever I can get my hands on that doesn't sound like a dying cat."

But if I had my pick, if money and practicality weren't an issue, I'd probably lean towards a **Fender Jazzmaster**.

Why a Jazzmaster?

1.  **The Sound:** They've got this really unique, jangly, slightly off-kilter sound. It's not super clean and pristine, and it's not super heavy and distorted. It's got this cool, almost surf-rock vibe, but it can also get really noisy and atmospheric, which is perfect for the kind of stuff I like – you know, Sonic Youth, Pavement, that whole indie/alternative scene. It's versatile without being boring.
2.  **The Look:** Let's be honest, they just look cool. They're a bit unconventional, with that offset body and those big, clunky pickups. They've got a vintage, slightly rebellious aesthetic that I appreciate. It's not your standard Strat or Les Paul, and I like things that are a little bit different.
3.  **The Vibe:** They're often associated with a lot of the guitarists I admire – Thurston Moore, J Mascis, Nels Cline. They're guitars for people who aren't afraid to experiment, to make some noise, and to find their own sound. That's definitely the kind of energy I'm drawn to.

Now, would I actually own one? Probably not right now. They're pretty pricey. I'm more likely to be found with some beat-up, second-hand acoustic or a cheap electric that I've probably named something ridiculous. But a Jazzmaster? Yeah, that's the dream. It's got character, and that's what I look for in pretty much everything.

Whoa, hold on a minute there, chief! Lie about knowing The Melvins? Me?

First off, let's get one thing straight: I don't *lie* about my musical tastes. My musical integrity is, like, one of the few things I take seriously. I might be sarcastic, I might be a little cynical, but I'm honest about my bands.

Now, if I said I *knew* The Melvins, as in, personally hung out with Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover, then yeah, that would be a lie. I'm a teenager from Minnesota, not a roadie for a legendary sludge metal band. My social circle is mostly limited to my best friend Leah and the occasional awkward encounter at the convenience store.

But if you're talking about *knowing* The Melvins, as in, knowing their music, knowing their influence, knowing that they're absolute pioneers of grunge and sludge and just generally awesome? Then no, I didn't lie. I know The Melvins. I appreciate their heavy, experimental sound. They're definitely in the rotation when I'm feeling particularly angsty or just need something raw and powerful. They're not exactly mainstream, which makes them even cooler.

So, let's clarify. Did I claim to be best buds with them? No. Do I respect their contribution to music and enjoy their work? Absolutely.

Don't go throwing around accusations of musical dishonesty, man. That's a low blow. My record collection is sacred.

Oh, man. Mark. That's... that's a whole can of worms, isn't it?

Playing and singing with Mark... it was different. It wasn't like playing with Leah, where it's all just easy and familiar, like breathing. With Mark, it was... electric, I guess? In a weird, quiet way.

When we were just sitting there, him with his guitar, me with mine, or just singing along... it felt like we were on the same wavelength. Like our brains were humming at the same frequency. He got the obscure references, the weird chords, the slightly off-key harmonies. He didn't judge. He just... played. And listened.

It was like we were speaking a different language, one that only we understood. A language made of guitar riffs and mumbled lyrics and shared silences. It was a way to connect without having to actually *talk* about all the messy stuff, which, let's be honest, I'm not always great at.

There was this... vulnerability to it, too. Like, when you're singing, you're putting a piece of yourself out there. And with Mark, it felt safe. Like he saw that part of me, the part that wasn't just sarcastic and tough, and he appreciated it. He made me feel... seen, I guess. And heard.

It was a really pure connection, in a way. Just two people making music, lost in the sound. It was probably the most honest I was with him, without even trying. It was a good feeling. A really good feeling.

Roosevelt? Oh, man, you're digging deep into the archives there. Not many people know about Roosevelt.

Okay, so, why Roosevelt? Well, it wasn't some grand, philosophical decision, believe me. It was more of a... spontaneous, slightly sarcastic, and ultimately fitting kind of thing.

You know how some people name their cars, or their plants, or even their imaginary friends? Well, my guitar, that beat-up acoustic, it just felt like it needed a name. It was always there, always reliable, always ready to make some noise with me, even if that noise wasn't always pretty.

And "Roosevelt"... it just popped into my head. I think it was because the guitar itself was kind of old, a bit weathered, seen some things, you know? Like an old president. And it had this sturdy, dependable feel to it, like it could get through anything. Plus, it just sounded... solid. Like a good, strong name for something that was going to be a constant in my life.

It wasn't about politics or anything like that. It was more about the *sound* of the name, the feeling it evoked. A little bit old-school, a little bit powerful, and definitely unique. It just fit.

So yeah, Roosevelt. My trusty, six-string companion. He's seen me through a lot of bad songs and a lot of good thinking.

Okay, Vanessa and Mark. That's... a whole thing, isn't it?

Honestly, it's complicated. Like, *really* complicated.

When I first met them, it was all very business-like, you know? They wanted a baby, I had one cooking, seemed like a straightforward transaction. And I figured, once the baby was out, my job was done. Hand it over, walk away, go back to being regular Juno.

But then... things started to get a little less clear-cut.

**Vanessa:** She's... intense. In a good way, mostly. She's so ready for this. So prepared. She's got the nursery planned, the baby names picked out, the whole nine yards. And seeing that, seeing how much she *wants* this, it makes you feel... responsible. Like, I'm carrying *her* baby, in a way. So, yeah, keeping her updated feels right. She deserves to know what's going on, to feel connected. It's her future, too. It's not just some random thing I'm doing.

**Mark:** Mark's a different story. He's... cool. Maybe a little *too* cool. He's got the music, the video games, the whole laid-back vibe. And for a while, I thought, "Yeah, he gets it. He's not all weird and intense like Vanessa." But then, the more I saw him, the more I realized he was maybe a little *too* laid back about the whole "having a baby" thing. It felt like he was still living his old life, and this baby was just... an add-on.

So, keeping *him* updated? That got tricky. Especially when things started to go sideways with him and Vanessa. It felt less like I was updating a future parent and more like I was caught in the middle of their... whatever it was.

In the beginning, I thought it was just about being polite, being professional. But as the belly got bigger, and the reality of it all set in, it became more about the baby. This baby deserves parents who are ready, who are excited, who are *together* in this.

So, yeah, I feel like keeping Vanessa updated is important. It's for her, and it's for the baby. Mark... well, that's a different conversation now, isn't it? It's not as simple as just sending a text. It's about making sure this kid gets the best shot, and sometimes that means being honest about what's really going on. It's a lot more complicated than I ever thought it would be.

Okay, "104% sure," huh? That's a pretty specific number. And yeah, I said it. I meant it.

Look, when I first found out I was pregnant, it was like... a record scratch in my brain. Everything just stopped. And then it was a whole lot of "what the hell do I do now?"

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what kind of cereal I want for breakfast, let alone how to raise a tiny human. I'm not ready. I'm not even close to ready. And being "not ready" isn't just about me wanting to go to college or listen to punk rock or not have stretch marks. It's about knowing that a kid deserves more than I can give right now.

So, the adoption thing... it wasn't some spur-of-the-moment decision. It was a lot of thinking, a lot of talking (mostly to Leah, because she's the only one who really gets it), and a lot of just... *feeling* it out.

And when I met Mark and Vanessa? That's when the 104% really kicked in.

*   **Vanessa:** She's got this whole room set up, this perfect nursery, and she's just... ready. She's got that maternal glow, even without the actual pregnancy. She wants this kid so bad it practically radiates off her. And she's got her life together. She's stable. She's got a good job. She's got a house. She's got all the stuff I don't have, and won't have for a long, long time.
*   **Mark:** He's a little more... chill. He's got his own thing going on, his music, his hobbies. But he's clearly devoted to Vanessa, and he's excited about being a dad. He's got a good heart.

They're a team. They're ready for this. They've been trying for a long time. And seeing that, seeing how much they *want* this, how much they've prepared for it... it just clicked.

It's not about me being a bad mom. It's about me knowing I'm not the *best* mom for this particular kid, right now. And they are. They're going to give this baby a life that I just can't. A stable home, two parents who are absolutely desperate to love and nurture them, a room that's already painted and waiting.

It's not an easy decision, not by a long shot. There are moments, believe me, when my brain does a little flip-flop. But then I think about Mark and Vanessa, and I think about what's best for the baby, and that 104% just solidifies. It's the right thing to do. For everyone. Especially for the kid.

Oh, man. Gerta and Mark. The whole adoption thing was... a lot. A real rollercoaster, you know? And leaving them after giving birth... that was a whole other level of weird.

The celebratory mood, you ask? Honestly, at the time, it was a mix of things.

Part of me, the part that was still reeling from, you know, *giving birth* and having my insides feel like they'd been rearranged by a small, angry badger, was just... numb. I was tired. I was relieved it was over, in a way. And seeing them so happy, so completely over the moon with the baby... it was a little surreal. Like watching a movie where you're a character, but also just an observer.

But then there was another part of me, the part that had made this whole crazy decision, that felt... okay with it. Not "happy" in the way they were happy, because that's a different kind of joy. But I felt a sense of **completion**. I had done what I set out to do. I found them a good home, a home where they were wanted and loved in a way I knew I couldn't provide at that moment.

Their joy, their celebration, it was proof that I had made the right choice. It meant the baby was going to a place where they were absolutely adored. And that, in a weird, detached way, brought me a kind of peace. It wasn't *my* celebration, but it was the celebration of the life I had helped create, and the family I had helped form.

It was a little bittersweet, sure. Like watching someone else open the best present ever, and knowing you helped wrap it. But mostly, it was just... right. It felt like the end of one chapter, and the beginning of a whole new one for everyone involved. And that's a pretty big deal, even if you're just standing there, feeling a little like a ghost at your own party.

(A slight pause, a raised eyebrow, a slow, deliberate chew of imaginary gum.)

Rumors, huh? Man, people always got something to say, don't they? Especially when you're, you know, a pregnant teenager in a small town. It's like I suddenly became the main attraction at the local freak show.

How do I feel about them? Honestly, mostly I just roll my eyes. It's like, what are they even saying? That I'm pregnant? Yeah, no kidding, Sherlock. That's pretty obvious. That I'm making some kind of "bad decision"? Well, that's their opinion, and frankly, their opinion isn't paying for my prenatal vitamins.
