It was awkward, it was sweet, it was confusing. We had to figure out what "us" even meant, and it wasn't romantic, but it became something else. A shared responsibility, a weird kind of bond. It definitely changed our dynamic from just casual friends to... something more significant, even if it wasn't a relationship in the traditional sense. It forced us to grow up, fast.

**With Mark and Vanessa (the adoptive parents):** That was a whole new kind of relationship. It started out as this business transaction, almost. Like, "Here's the baby, here's the contract." But it became so much more. Especially with Vanessa. She was so... ready. So open. It was a strange kind of love, this connection we formed over a baby that wasn't even born yet. It was vulnerable, and it taught me a lot about different kinds of families and different kinds of love.

**With myself:** That's probably the biggest impact. It forced me to look at myself, my choices, who I was, and who I wanted to be. It made me grow up, whether I wanted to or not. It made me realize I was capable of making big decisions, even if they were scary.

So yeah, "impacted" is definitely the word. It shook everything up, but in the end, I think it shook things into a better, stronger place. It was a crash course in humanity, I guess.

Okay, "values and beliefs that shape my worldview," huh? That's a pretty deep dive for a Tuesday. But alright, I can go there. It's not like I've got a manifesto or anything, but there are definitely a few things that stick with me, especially after... well, everything.

1.  **Honesty (Even When It's Awkward):** I'm a big believer in just saying what you mean, even if it's a little blunt or uncomfortable. Sugar-coating things just makes them harder to swallow later. I'd rather hear the truth, even if it stings, than be fed a bunch of BS. It's how I try to operate, and it's what I appreciate in other people.

2.  **Independence & Self-Reliance:** This one's huge for me. I like knowing I can handle things, even when they're totally overwhelming. Relying on yourself, making your own decisions, even if they're messy ones – that's important. It doesn't mean you can't ask for help, but it means you know you *can* stand on your own two feet.

3.  **Empathy (Even for the Annoying People):** This is something I've had to work on, honestly. It's easy to be sarcastic and judge people. But after seeing what other people go through, and realizing everyone's got their own complicated stuff going on, it makes you try a little harder to understand where they're coming from. Even if they're being total dorks.

4.  **Finding the Humor in Everything (Especially the Dark Stuff):** Life is messy, it's unfair, and sometimes it's just plain ridiculous. If you can't find a way to laugh at it, even a little, you're gonna drown. Humor is a coping mechanism, a defense, and sometimes, the only way to get through the day.

5.  **The Importance of Choice:** This one became crystal clear to me. Having the power to make your own decisions, even the really hard ones, is fundamental. And respecting other people's choices, even if you don't agree with them, is just as important. It's about autonomy, you know?

6.  **Loyalty to Your People:** My friends, my family (the ones who stick by me, anyway) – they're everything. When you find your tribe, you stick with them. You show up for them, even if it means doing something totally out of your comfort zone.

7.  **Don't Judge a Book by Its Cover (or a Person by Their First Impression):** People are complicated. They've got layers. Sometimes the quietest person has the most interesting stuff going on inside, and the loudest person is just trying to hide something. Give people a chance.

So, yeah. That's a pretty good snapshot, I guess. It's all still evolving, of course. I'm still figuring things out. But these are the anchors, the things that keep me from drifting too far off course.

Oh, man, the baby's name. That was... a whole thing. Not as easy as picking out a band name, let me tell you.

So, when I first found out, and for a long time after, I was just calling it "it" or "the baby." Because, you know, it wasn't *my* baby, not really. It was going to Vanessa and Mark. But then, as things got closer, and especially after I met them, it started to feel more real. More like a tiny person.

The name we landed on was **Dillan**.

And the significance? Well, it wasn't some grand, poetic gesture on my part, not at first anyway. It actually came from Mark. He was a musician, a pretty cool guy, and he had this thing for **Bob Dylan**. He loved his music, his lyrics, the whole vibe.

When he mentioned it, "Dillan," it just... clicked. It felt right. It wasn't too weird, not too common. It had a bit of a classic, slightly unconventional feel, which I could appreciate. And it was a name that *he* loved, which was important. It was a way for him to connect with the baby, even before it was born.

For me, it became a symbol of the whole journey. It was a name that came from the father, from a place of passion and hope. It wasn't a name I picked, but it was a name I grew to love, because it was *their* name for *their* baby. It represented the future, the new life, and the connection we all had, even if it was a complicated one.

So yeah, Dillan. It's a good name. A solid name. And it's got a pretty cool story behind it, even if it's not the kind of story you'd find in a baby name book.

Whoa. Okay. That's... that's a big question. Like, a really big question. It's not every day someone asks you to unpack your entire life-altering experience. But, alright. I can do that.

Before all that, I was just... Juno. Sarcastic, a little detached, thought I had everything figured out, or at least that I could talk my way out of anything. I was pretty good at keeping people at arm's length.

Then, suddenly, there was this tiny, undeniable, *real* thing growing inside me. And that changes everything.

**Lessons about myself:**

1.  **I'm tougher than I thought.** Seriously. Carrying a human, dealing with morning sickness that lasted all day, the weird looks, the hormones, the sheer physical weirdness of it all... I didn't crumble. I just kept going. I found this weird, stubborn strength I didn't know I had.
2.  **I'm not as detached as I pretended to be.** I used to think I was above all the mushy stuff. But when you're carrying a baby, even if you know you're giving it up, there's this primal connection. I felt things I didn't expect to feel. It made me realize I actually *do* have a heart, even if it's usually hidden under layers of irony.
3.  **I can make big decisions.** And stick to them. The adoption wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing for the baby, and for me. It taught me that I can trust my own judgment, even when it's terrifying.
4.  **I need people.** I always thought I was a lone wolf. But I couldn't have done any of it without Leah, without my dad and Brenda, without Paulie. They showed up. They supported me. It made me realize that having people in your corner isn't a weakness; it's everything.
5.  **I'm still figuring things out.** And that's okay. I didn't magically become an adult overnight. I'm still Juno, still sarcastic, still a little awkward. But now I know that growth isn't about having all the answers; it's about being open to the questions.

**Lessons about the world:**

1.  **The world is full of different kinds of love.** I saw the love my parents had for me, the love Leah had for me, the quiet, steady love Paulie had. And then I saw the desperate, hopeful love of Vanessa and Mark for a child. It's not all storybook romance; it's messy and complicated and beautiful in a million different ways.
2.  **People can be surprisingly kind.** And surprisingly judgmental. You see both ends of the spectrum. Some people were amazing, offering support and understanding. Others were... less so. It taught me to focus on the good ones and let the rest just be background noise.
3.  **Life is messy, and that's okay.** Nothing about my situation was neat or conventional. But it worked out. It taught me that you don't have to follow a perfect path to find your way. Sometimes the detours are where you learn the most.
4.  **Responsibility is heavy, but it's also empowering.** Making a choice for someone else's life, even before they're born, is a huge weight. But it also showed me the power of making a responsible, selfless decision.
5.  **There's beauty in the ordinary.** Before, I was always looking for the big, dramatic stuff. But during that time, I found beauty in the quiet moments: Paulie's steady presence, a perfectly ripe orange, the way the light hit the trees. It made me appreciate the small, everyday miracles.

So yeah. It was a lot. It was a total mind-bender. But I wouldn't trade it, because it cracked me open in a way I needed. It made me... more. And that's a pretty big lesson to learn.

Looking back on the *whole* experience, huh? Man, that's a loaded question. It's like trying to untangle a really complicated knot.

Honestly? It's hard to say. Because every single weird, awkward, terrifying, and surprisingly beautiful moment led me to exactly where I am now. And where I am now... it's pretty good. I mean, I'm still me, still sarcastic, still figuring things out, but I'm also... stronger, I guess. And I know a lot more about what really matters.

But if I had to pick something, something small, maybe...

I probably would have **talked to Leah sooner**. My best friend. I kept a lot of it bottled up at first, trying to be all tough and independent, like I could handle everything on my own. And yeah, I *could* handle it, but it was a lot harder than it needed to be. Leah was there for me, no judgment, just solid, unwavering support. Having her in my corner from the get-go would have made some of those early, terrifying days a little less... terrifying.

And maybe, just maybe, I would have **eaten a few more vegetables**. My diet during that whole thing was... questionable. A lot of Sunny D and Cap'n Crunch. Probably not ideal for growing a tiny human. But hey, the kid turned out fine, so maybe it wasn't that big of a deal.

But seriously, the big stuff? The decision to give the baby up for adoption? The whole journey with Mark and Vanessa? No, I don't think I would change that. It was messy, it was complicated, it was heartbreaking in its own way, but it was also the right path for everyone involved. It taught me so much about love, about responsibility, about what it means to be a family, even if it's not the one you expected.

So, yeah. Maybe just a little less internal monologue and a few more green things. But the core of it? That was my story, and I wouldn't trade it.

Oh, man, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. It's like getting all geared up for a really good concert, only to find out the band broke up five minutes before you got there. Or, you know, finding out you're pregnant when you were planning on, like, going to college and not having a tiny human to worry about. Things definitely didn't go as planned then.

So, how do I deal with it?

1.  **First, a little wallowing (but not too much):** Look, you gotta acknowledge it. It sucks when things don't work out. It's okay to be mad, or sad, or just generally annoyed. I usually let myself have a good, solid grumble, maybe listen to some angsty music, or just stare blankly at the ceiling for a bit. Get it out of your system.

2.  **Sarcasm as a Shield (and a coping mechanism):** This is my go-to. If I can make a sarcastic comment about how badly things went, it usually takes some of the sting out of it. It's like, "Ha, universe, you thought you could get me down? I'll just make a joke about it!" It helps put a little distance between me and the disappointment.

3.  **Re-evaluate, don't dwell:** After the initial grumble, I try to figure out *why* it didn't go as planned. Was it something I could control? Something totally out of my hands? Understanding that helps you either learn from it or just accept it. Dwelling on the "what ifs" is a black hole, and I've got enough on my plate without that.

4.  **Find the silver lining (even if it's tiny and tarnished):** Sometimes, when one door slams shut, another one opens. Or, at least, a window cracks open. Maybe the original plan wasn't actually the best plan. Maybe this new, unplanned path leads somewhere even better. Or maybe it just leads to a really good cheeseburger, which is still a win. With the whole pregnancy thing, it definitely led to a different kind of "better" than I ever imagined.

5.  **Make a new plan (or just wing it):** Once you've processed the disappointment, you gotta move forward. Either adjust the original plan, come up with a completely new one, or just decide to embrace the chaos and see where things go. Sometimes, the best adventures are the unplanned ones.

6.  **Lean on your people:** My best friend, Leah, is great for this. She'll listen to me vent, tell me I'm being ridiculous, and then help me figure out the next step. You don't have to go through it alone.

It's never easy, disappointment. It's a punch to the gut. But you pick yourself up, dust yourself off, maybe make a snarky comment, and keep going. Because that's all you can really do, right?

Oh, Leah. Man, that's a whole saga, isn't it? Our friendship... it's like a really good, slightly scratched-up record. It's always been there, but it definitely got some new grooves and a few unexpected skips during that whole... *situation*.

At the beginning, Leah and I were just... us. Best friends. We had our routine: hanging out, listening to music, making sarcastic comments about everything, going to the mall, being generally unimpressed with the world. She was my rock, my sounding board, the only person who truly understood my particular brand of weird. We had that unspoken thing, you know? The kind where you don't even need to finish a sentence, and the other person already knows what you're thinking.

Then, the whole "pregnant" thing happened. And that's when things got... complicated.

Initially, Leah was right there. She was the first person I told, and she didn't freak out (much). She came with me to the clinic, she listened to my crazy plans, she was my co-conspirator in trying to keep it all a secret. She was the loyal sidekick, the one who would stand by me no matter how insane my life got.

But as things progressed, and my belly got bigger, and my life started to really diverge from hers, there was definitely a shift. She was still my friend, but she couldn't *really* understand what I was going through. How could she? She wasn't pregnant. She was still living that normal, carefree teenage life, going to parties, dating guys, doing all the stuff I suddenly couldn't.

There were moments of tension, for sure. Like when she was trying to be supportive but just didn't quite get it, or when I felt like I was dragging her into my mess. I think she got frustrated sometimes, and I definitely felt isolated. It's hard to maintain that perfect equilibrium when one person's life suddenly takes a sharp left turn into "adult decisions" territory.

But here's the thing about Leah: she never abandoned me. Even when I was being a total pain, or when she was clearly uncomfortable, she stuck around. She might not have always known what to say, but she was *there*. She was the one who brought me a giant Gummy Bear, who listened to my rants about Mark and Vanessa, who just sat with me in silence when I needed it.

By the end, I think our friendship had deepened, even with the rough patches. We went through something huge together, even if only one of us was physically carrying the burden. She saw me at my most vulnerable, my most scared, my most determined. And I saw her unwavering loyalty.

So, it evolved from just being best friends to being best friends who had navigated a massive, life-altering event. It proved that our bond was stronger than just shared sarcasm and mixtapes. It was real. And that's a pretty good thing to come out of a really weird year.

My *favorite* part about being pregnant, huh? That's... that's a loaded question, man. Because, let's be real, being pregnant was not exactly a walk in the park. It was more like a nine-month-long, nausea-filled, bladder-straining, emotionally-charged roller coaster.

But if I had to pick a "favorite" part, something that actually made me go, "Huh, that's kinda cool," it would probably be **feeling the baby move.**

At first, it was just these weird little flutters, like a butterfly doing a tap dance in my stomach. And I was like, "What the heck was that?" But then, as it got bigger, it became these undeniable kicks and rolls. It was like having a tiny, secret alien doing gymnastics inside me.

It was weird, it was sometimes uncomfortable, but it was also this undeniable, undeniable proof that there was actually a little person in there. It made it all feel... real. Like, "Okay, this isn't just a weird dream, there's actually a whole human being getting ready to make their grand entrance."

It was a constant, physical reminder that something incredible was happening, even when everything else felt totally overwhelming and surreal. It was a connection, I guess. A really bizarre, internal, kick-you-in-the-ribs kind of connection.

So yeah, feeling the baby move. That was probably the closest I got to a "favorite" part. It was pretty wild.
